abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>SARS-CoV-2 has spread rapidly across the world and is negatively impacting the global human population. COVID-19 patients display a wide variety of symptoms and clinical outcomes, including those attributed to genetic ancestry. <jats:italic>Alu</jats:italic> retrotransposons have played an important role in human evolution, and their variants influence host response to viral infection. Intronic <jats:italic>Alu</jats:italic>s regulate gene expression through several mechanisms, including both genetic and epigenetic pathways. With respect to SARS-CoV-2, an intronic <jats:italic>Alu</jats:italic> within the <jats:italic>ACE</jats:italic> gene is hypothesized to be associated with COVID-19 susceptibility and morbidity. Here, we review specific <jats:italic>Alu</jats:italic> polymorphisms that are of particular interest when considering host response to SARS-CoV-2 infection, especially polymorphic <jats:italic>Alu</jats:italic> insertions in genes associated with immune response and coagulation/fibrinolysis cascade. We posit that additional research focused on <jats:italic>Alu</jats:italic>-related pathways could yield novel biomarkers capable of predicting clinical outcomes as well as patient-specific treatment strategies for COVID-19 and related infectious diseases.</jats:p>
